docs.lead_paragraph: Aaron Feuerstein, the chairman of Malden Mills Industries who became a national folk hero for his loyalty to his workers, is backing away from a promise to preserve the jobs of all 3,200 employees at the family-owned textile company in Lawrence, Mass. Starting on Friday, he and his executives have been notifying 450 employees that they must look elsewhere for jobs because the company cannot rebuild quickly enough to need them before late next year, at the earliest.

headline.main: Chief Who Preserved Mill Jobs Is Now Cutting 450 Positions

docs.lead_paragraph: The men and women running Bob Dole's Presidential campaign are happy to tell people what Elizabeth Dole is not. She is not, they say, Hillary Clinton, and she would not be an unelected policy maker as First Lady. But recent interviews suggest that Mrs. Dole is in fact operating very much like Mrs. Clinton, and that the difference is one of semantics. The same senior advisers who characterize Mrs. Dole as "not Mrs. Clinton" readily admit that Mrs. Dole is her husband's closest adviser, with influence over policy and staff. They also call her the candidate's "chief surrogate," one who campaigns six days a week, mostly without Mr. Dole, to raise money and strengthen his support among groups like women and the Christian right.

headline.main: THE OTHER DOLE -- A special report.;Elizabeth Dole Is Eager To Keep Strength Subtle

docs.lead_paragraph: Four months before Election Day, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s advertising campaign has buffeted House Republicans from coast to coast, forcing them on the defensive on issues like Medicare and generating a fierce counterattack from Republicans and their allies that is expected to broaden in the weeks to come. Already, some analysts say, labor has played more of a role in the political debate than it has since 1984, when it was front and center in the Presidential campaign of Walter F. Mondale. Its television and radio campaign, primarily focused on the districts of Republican freshmen in the House, has presented a harrowing critique of the 104th Congress and made it harder for many Republicans to regain their political footing after last year's bruising budget battle, several leading pollsters say.

headline.main: Battered by Labor's Ads, Republicans Strike Back

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Elliott Vichinsky runs a large program at Children's Hospital in Oakland, Calif., that specializes in the treatment of two genetic blood disorders -- sickle-cell anemia, which occurs most often in black people, and thalassemia, which is frequently found in people of Mediterranean and Southeast Asian origin. Not long ago he had as a patient a teen-age girl with sickle-cell anemia whose mother was on public assistance. While describing this case in an interview last week, he noted that some sickle-cell patients suffer from hemiplegia, a paralysis affecting one side of the body that is caused by a blockage of blood vessels in the brain.

docs.lead_paragraph: Millions of New Yorkers have recently enrolled in H.M.O.'s, and most have slowly learned to navigate the system. But a growing number, mostly with chronic conditions or serious diseases, say they are being denied desperately needed care. And instead of battling their illness, they find themselves fighting with their health plans for permission to get treatment. Health experts say that many plans in New York's young and rapidly expanding managed-care industry have not developed the physician networks or the treatment programs required to handle patients with complicated medical needs. While mature health maintenance organizations exist in other parts of the country, the experts say, they are uncommon in a number of cities like New York and Boston, where managed care is still young.

headline.main: COMPLICATIONS IN CARE -- A special report.;Patients With Difficult Illnesses Fight New H.M.O.'s to Get Help

docs.lead_paragraph: In San Francisco, as he picked up the newspaper each day last week, Armistead Maupin almost could not believe all the good news cascading south from the international AIDS conference in Vancouver, British Columbia. In New York, Mario M. Cooper realized that he might be able to ratchet up the pace of his career again, having walked away from a high-pressure existence because he had the AIDS virus.

headline.main: From AIDS Conference, Talk of Life, Not Death
